# Category Theory

# Constructions

# Coproduct

Let C\mathcal{C}C be a category and let X,YX,YX,Y be objects in this category. An object is called the coproduct of these two objects, written as X⊕YX \oplus YX⊕Y or X⊔YX \sqcup YX⊔Y, if there exist morphisms iX:X→X⊕Yi_{X}: X \rightarrow X \oplus YiX​:X→X⊕Y and iY:Y→X⊕Yi_{Y}: Y \rightarrow X \oplus YiY​:Y→X⊕Y satisfying a universal property: for any object ZZZ and morphisms fX:X→Zf_{X}: X \rightarrow ZfX​:X→Z and fY:Y→Zf_{Y}: Y \rightarrow ZfY​:Y→Z, there xsits a unique morphism f:X⊕Y→Zf: X \oplus Y \rightarrow Zf:X⊕Y→Z such that fX=f∘iXf_{X} = f \circ i_{X}fX​=f∘iX​ and fY=f∘iYf_{Y} = f \circ i_{Y}fY​=f∘iY​.
